Graham Hovey — Letter from Italy No. 6
Recorded in Rome December 20, 1953
Tape runs 13*30
This is Graham Hovey, reporting from Rome with another radio
Letter from Italy. These programs are produced for the National Associa¬
tion of Educational Broadcasters with the cooperation of Radio Italians.
A big poster on a building near my apartment says that the Hon.
Pietro Secchia will address a meeting of the Federation of Italian
Communist Youth on Sunday at the Adriano theater.
The poster says that Signor Secchia, the vice secretary general
of the Italian Communist party, will launch the Federation*a drive for new
members. And it says that the goal for 1954 is 40,000 young Communists in
Rome and the region of Lazio.
This poster was pasted over another which you can still make out.
This earlier poster says that two party leaders will speak at the Adriano
theater on Sunday about plans for the future of Rome and the Lazio region.
The speakers were the Hon. Edoardo D’Onofrio, vice president of the Italian
Chamber of Deputies, and Aldo Natoli, regional secretary of the Communist
party for Lazio.
This second poster had been pasted over a third one put up a week
earlier. This third poster said that the Hon. Giuseppe di Vittorio would
speak on Sunday at the Adriano theater about the demands for wage increases
by workers in state-owned industries. Signor di Vittorio is secretary-
general of the Communist-dominated Italian General Confederation of Labor.
If you could dig back beyond that third poster you would find that
four weeks ago the Hon. Palmiro Togllatti, secretary general of the party,
addressed a Sunday meeting at the Adriano theater, and that five weeks ago
the speaker was Luigi Longo, the hardboiled party organizer.
An American in Rome sometimes gets the feeling that the Communists
will win Italy in the end simply because they are willing to work harder at
the Job than all the democratic parties combined.
Sfals impression might not be accurate. There is more to winning
an election, more to taking over Italy, than Just winning the battle of the
posters or having Sunday morning meetings in the Adriano theater.
Still, I believe Americans should not dismiss this poster business
lightly — for two reasons* the posters themselves surely have some propa¬
ganda value for the Communists. And they do, in fact, signify serious party
activity. Those meetings in the Adriano theater actually come off. And they
are well attended.
One reason why they are well attended is that the Communist leaders
speak only rarely about the Soviet Union and world communism. I noticed that
even the poster announcing that Signor Togllatti would speak on the 36th
anniversary of the October revolution did not say whose revolution or where
It took place. There was no mention of the Soviet Union.
And note what the others were to talk about* Pietro Secchia, the
strong man of the Italian Communist party; the real boss of the party's hard
core, was to speak to the youth. He was to tell them about Communist plans
for making their future brighter than it now Is in Italy.
